hl1: Hub students make strong argument for debate teams
author: JESSICA HESLAM
lede: Charlestown High School junior and aspiring lawyer Mohammad Umar was so nervous at the start of his first debate tournament last year that his left leg was shaking. But Umar's nerves were put at ease after he won the first round debating Cuba's embargo. He gave coach James Soares a high-five and said: 'Sign me up for the next tournament. I love it.'
body: Umar, 17, now a team captain, said debating has improved his writing, reading and public speaking skills.  'I feel like I am much, much more confident,' Umar said. Success stories like his are behind a massive plan to start debate teams at every public middle and high school in Boston. A Georgia State University study on Boston's debate program found that students who joined debate teams have higher grades, higher test scores and are more likely to take and pass AP tests than those not on debate teams, said Steve Stein, executive director of the Boston Debate League, a nonprofit that works with BPS to start debate teams, run tournaments and train teachers as debate coaches. The Debate League began about nine years ago with three Hub schools and is now in 28 middle and high schools. Over the next five to seven years, Stein said, the goal is to have a debate team in each of the city's 75 middle and high schools. The $2 million annual budget - heavily supported by corporate donations and foundations - is expected to triple.  'We'd love to see a day where thousands of students are graduating from BPS every year trained in debate,' said Stein, who said the program has helped students struggling the most, 'especially male students of color.' Over the past seven years, Stein said they've been 'intentionally recruiting' students who struggle with academics, those with behavioral problems and those who are learning English. They found that the students 'loved debate,' Stein said. Last year, a pilot program in Spanish was launched. The students debate serious public policy topics - this year it's ocean exploration and development. They practice after school and compete in six tournaments a year. At Charlestown High yesterday, Umar and Joshua Rosa, his debate partner and fellow captain, were gearing up for this week's Citi Foundation Championships. Joshua, a 17-year-old junior, said he was hooked after winning his first round in a debate tournament. His public speaking skills have improved and he wants to study pre-law or pre-med at NYU. 'In class, I'm more engaged and more involved in the discussions,' he said. Said coach Soares: 'It's such an amazing way to empower students.'

author: Adriana Cohen
lede: With all the threats facing our closest ally in the Middle East, Israelis must pull the lever for Bibi one more time. The future of their country - and peace in the Middle East - depends on it.
body: If Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu loses his re-election bid today, the winner is Iran, Hamas, Hezbollah and radical jihadists worldwide who hate Israel, the United States and every freedom Western civilization stands for. Yet despite Netanyahu's unwavering friendship and wise counsel to the United States, President Obama and U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry will be cheering his defeat, as well as dozens of other misguided Democrats who boycotted Netanyahu's recent historic speech before Congress about Iran's nuclear threat. It's an utter travesty we had to receive that warning, and a much-needed explanation of the cataclysmic consequences that failed nuke talks would undoubtedly yield, from a foreign leader instead of from our own president. It's obvious Obama and Kerry are more interested in coming to an agreement with Iran that's a public relations 'win' for them first versus crafting a pact that actually keeps Israel and future generations safe from harm. Americans don't want our president to kick the nuclear can down the road.  Netanyahu explained in his speech that Iran already has nuclear capability that can reach America's shores. And we know there's no safe haven from our other enemies - such as ISIS - accessing and utilizing dirty bombs or warheads in the future. A new report says the Kurds are accusing ISIS fighters of using chemical weapons in their ongoing Holy War against humanity. Will the Islamic State turn down an opportunity to amplify its power and influence tenfold by getting a nuke in the future?  You can bet your last dollar the answer is no.  What we know for sure is that once Iran completes its nuclear program, it will trigger a nuclear arms race in the Middle East, making America and the world a much less safe place.  All the more reason Israelis need to re-elect one of the finest leaders of the free world, Benjamin Netanyahu. He's an honest and fearless leader who shares our interests and has America's back. lede: The manhunt for the Tsarnaev brothers erupted in the early morning of April 19, 2013, in Watertown. This is how federal prosecutors and witnesses said it all went down:
body: As Watertown police Sgts. Jeffrey Pugliese, John MacLellan and patrolman Joseph Reynolds struggle to subdue and handcuff a wounded Tamerlan Tsarnaev in the middle of Laurel Street after 10 minutes of gunfire and bomb-throwing, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, still behind the brothers' Honda Civic, climbs into the driver's seat of the carjacked Mercedes-Benz ML350, executes a three-point turn and steams toward them at 35-40 mph, running over Tamerlan as the cops jump clear. Tamerlan, still alive, is shaken loose when Dzhokhar plows into Reynolds' parked cruiser before continuing across the intersection with Dexter Avenue.

author: MARK MURPHY / celtics notebook
lede: A new Garden folk hero appears to have been born. Luigi Datome, a native of Sardinia who was perhaps the finest Italian player in Serie A before he went to Detroit to languish on the bench, reemerged as one of Brad Stevens' best shooters off the bench.  And, as the Garden crowd demonstrated yet again during the swingman's 10-point performance last night, there's no shortage of appreciation.
body: 'I'm very surprised, but I think people are excited because it's somebody new,' Datome said after the Celtics' 108-89 win over Philadelphia. 'Brand new in this league, but, of course, the love from the fans is moving me on.' This is also the happiest Datome admittedly felt on an NBA roster. 'Last summer with the national team,' Datome replied when asked the last time he was this happy.  'I was thinking about it. I never had so many games in a row with real minutes, when the game counted. My goal when I came into the league was to show I belonged on this level, and coach Stevens gave me this opportunity. It's just fantastic.' Thomas a no-go As Stevens repeatedly said last night, nobody wants to get back on the basketball court more than Isaiah Thomas. If only the Celtics guard's bruised lower back agreed. Thomas got the bad news during a meeting with Celtics trainer Ed Lacerte yesterday morning. The pain in his back was still too intense to allow him to play last night, thus extending his absence to four straight games. And the time frame is worse.  The Celtics leave tomorrow for games in Oklahoma City and San Antonio, and Thomas will spend that time getting treatment here. 'He'll be reevaluated tomorrow, but right now I'd say it's unlikely he travels,' Stevens said before last night's game. 'He's still three games away, which is too bad. He really wants to play. To say he's antsy is an understatement.' No further tests have been deemed necessary for Thomas. 'Ed said it's as tough of a bruise as he's ever seen,' Stevens said. 'Nobody wants to play more than that kid. That's what I appreciate about him. He had himself convinced he would play the next day after he fell. Hopefully he gets better sooner rather than later. He's a tough kid. Nobody questions that. He's doing nothing running-wise, movement-wise. He started jogging on the treadmill. But he hasn't been able to push himself as much as he needed to.' College calling A source said that, if contacted, Celtics assistant Jay Larranaga will consider interviewing for the opening at George Mason, the program his dad Jim took to the 2006 Final Four. Larranaga is said to view it all with due diligence, as opposed to genuine interest, out of respect for his father's former program. 'He loves working for Brad (Stevens) and the Celtics,' said the source, indicating that it would take a very special situation - another NBA job - for Larranaga to leave the Celtics. A league source said that Larranaga, who interviewed for the 76ers job last season, can expect to be getting more calls from NBA teams. 'The reality is that I'd be surprised if Jay wants that job,' the source said. 'He's going to have chances at head NBA jobs. If he went to George Mason, that would hurt his chances.' Stevens said he certainly understands the interest. 'It would be smart to pursue him, but I don't know what his interests are,' he said. 'He's just a really good basketball guy. He's smart, he works really hard, he's positive. I've talked about our staff and how great they've been all year. Any of those guys would be good for opportunities like that. One thing I'm excited about is that I have a chance to work with those guys every day, because I learn more from them than they do from me.'

hl2: 'If you can't poke fun at yourself, you're not getting it'
author: O'RYAN JOHNSON and BOB MCGOVERN
lede: Gov. Charlie Baker is standing by his MBTA skit at South Boston's St. Patrick's Day Breakfast - and doubled down last night at another holiday dinner in Lowell, where he mocked the transit agency's dysfunctional commuter rail line.
body: 'It was an opportunity for all of us to sort of poke fun at ourselves, and let's face it, we all know it's been a long winter. The MBTA had some issues we worked pretty hard with them to fix,' Baker told the Herald last night. 'If you can't poke fun at yourself, you're not getting it.'  Baker drew some chuckles at the St. Patrick's Day fete in Lowell, when he joked that during the height of the storms he would be told a number of commuter rail engines were ready to go the next day - only to see that number shrink the following morning.  'I was like, what are these things, teenagers? 'I got up this morning, Dad looked at me kind of funny. I was out drinking last night. I'm sorry.' ... I wish I was kidding, but the simple truth is the main reason we had so much trouble with the commuter rail is because inside those big, brawny locomotives beats the heart of a 16-year-old,' Baker said.  'We've been doing everything we can to get them to grow up fast. We're told we have 50 of them ready to go tomorrow morning,' he said. 'As long as nobody has any exams - or nobody wants to celebrate St. Patrick's Day with their friends - we should be fine in the morning.'  Baker got mixed reviews Sunday when he appeared in a video with event emcee, state Sen. Linda Dorcena Forry, waiting for a late bus to take them to the breakfast. Departing T general manager Beverly Scott then pulls up behind the wheel and hopes out loud that there's 'absolutely no reason to put you in the back of the bus,' before telling the governor to 'buckle up.' Newly minted Attorney General Maura Healey also drew some heat for holding up several fake subpoenas at the Sunday breakfast, and jokingly telling lawmakers in the crowd, 'Some of you might be familiar with these. So laugh.' Santa Clara University Law School professor Margalynne Armstrong found the joke inappropriate for the state's top lawwoman. 'She needs to make sure she gives the office the respect it deserves. It's important to not treat her power lightly,' Armstrong said. 'The decent thing to do would be to apologize. And it should be a real apology.'  Healey noted she didn't catch any flak for the joke. 'No, not for that. For a bad performance, maybe. Not that part of the performance, no,' she told the Herald. 'Was I supposed to? It was a joke. It's a roast.' She also said the subpoenas were obvious props.  'They didn't have the right seal,' she said. 'Did you see them? They were like Crayola subpoenas.'

author: RED SOX BEAT by SCOTT LAUBER
lede: FORT MYERS - Gather 'round, wannabe Red Sox aces (we're talking to you, Clay Buchholz; look alive, Rick Porcello): Uncle Pedro has a story to tell. 'I got into Montreal (in 1994) and I had just come from being a reliever with the Dodgers,' Pedro Martinez was saying the other day. '(Manager) Felipe (Alou) called me into the office one day in spring training and he handed me a ball and said, 'Pedro, you're my No. 4 starter.' I'm like, 'Oh, really? Thank you so much for the opportunity.' And he goes, 'Don't worry about being No. 4, because after the first three guys pitch, you're the No. 1. You have to feel like a No. 1 every time you take the mound.' ' Now, surely Martinez knows that being a No. 1 starter is more than a state of mind. He didn't become the greatest pitcher of his generation, to say nothing of a first-ballot Hall of Famer, by virtue of having extreme self-confidence. The blazing fastball, knees-knocking curve, bat-slowing changeup (that might only be the nastiest pitch ever thrown) and the fearlessness to brush back any hitter undoubtedly had more to do with it.
body: And after a week-long visit to fulfill his duties as a special instructor and assistant to general manager Ben Cherington, Martinez also must know the Red Sox lack a pitcher with real No. 1-starter bona fides. Jon Lester isn't walking through the clubhouse door. Neither is Philadelphia Phillies ace Cole Hamels, for whom the Sox made a trade offer that one MLB source recently labeled as 'poor.' It's difficult to imagine they won't eventually obtain such an alpha pitcher, especially with principal owner John Henry green-lighting a record payroll that will approach $200 million for luxury tax purposes. But in the meantime, it behooves everyone in the organization to help instill enough confidence in Buchholz, Porcello and the other starters that they believe any of them are capable of taking the lead. And that's the tune Martinez is singing. 'A guy like Hamels, like Lester, top-notch starters, they're welcome in any team,' Martinez said. 'But if they're not here, I would be saying, 'Hey, I'm capable. Hamels was once what I am today, so why not me?' That would be the question I would have. I think they have to walk around with that same attitude - why not me, or why not us? Why can't we all be aces?' So, Martinez loves the customized 'He's the ACE' T-shirts that Buchholz ordered and distributed to Porcello, Justin Masterson, Joe Kelly and lefty Wade Miley to wear around the clubhouse before games. It shows 'character,' he says, and demonstrates the attitude he believes the starters need to have. Of course, proven aces don't need T-shirts. When Mets right-hander Matt Harvey scaled the mound yesterday at JetBlue Park, everyone knew they were about to see one of the majors' best. The same went for Martinez in his 201 starts for the Sox from 1998-2004. 'Any one of these guys could be the stopper,' Martinez said. 'They were just never put in this spot. And this (Red Sox) team is no joke. This team is going to put up some runs. This team is going to produce for them.' Ironically, people were saying the same thing about the Red Sox 10 years ago, after Martinez left to sign with the Mets. With Curt Schilling injured, the 2005 Sox went through most of the season with an ace-less rotation that consisted of David Wells, Matt Clement, Tim Wakefield, Bronson Arroyo and Wade Miller, only one of whom (Wakefield) posted an ERA below the league average. That team won 95 games and made the playoffs on the back of an offense that scored 910 runs but got swept out of the playoffs by the Chicago White Sox' superior starters. Still, Martinez is bullish on the potential of this year's rotation. He's impressed by Kelly's talent, and noted that Masterson was the Cleveland Indians' best pitcher for much of the 2013 season. He believes Porcello is 'showing signs of someone that could become the ace of the team,' and described Buchholz as 'going about his work like he's got a purpose.' Maybe so. But is there an ace in the bunch? Here, again, we yield to Uncle Pedro. 'My advice to those guys: Feel like you're the ace every single time you take the mound,' Martinez said. 'They know what they need to do. I'm not concerned, to be honest.'

hl1: MO COWAN PARTNER IN MCCA HOTEL BID
hl2: Ex-U.S. sen once served on convention center board
author: RICHARD WEIR
lede: Former U.S. Sen. William 'Mo' Cowan - a onetime board member of the state convention center authority - is an equity partner in an $800 million Seaport District hotel that's being proposed as part of the agency's controversial $1 billion expansion, the Herald has learned. Cowan, who also served as former Gov. Deval Patrick's chief of staff and chief legal counsel, and another former member of the Massachusetts Convention Center Authority's board, Dean Stratouly, both have ownership stakes in the Omni Hotel & Resorts-backed 'headquarters hotel' project. It is one of six bids to build a 1,000- to 1,200-room, $800 million hotel across from the convention center.
body: Cowan was tapped by Patrick in February 2013 to replace John F. Kerry in the U.S. Senate until Edward J. Markey won the seat in a special election five months later.  Cowan told the Herald in an email he did not see any conflict being an equity partner in the hotel after serving on the board that will decide on his bid. 'I do not discuss my personal investment decisions,' said Cowan, now a lawyer at Mintz Levin, when asked how much money he has invested for his equity stake.  Cowan, who served on the board from February 2008 to November 2010, also confirmed he is friends with Greg Shell, husband of the panel's current chairwoman, Michelle A. Shell. Stratouly - who served on the MCCA board from February 1998 to June 2010, and chaired its building committee - also downplayed perceptions that his project might be looked on more favorably due to his longtime ties with the MCCA. 'I am not quite sure how it would be a conflict of interest given the amount of time that has lapsed for either me or Mo' since serving on the board, Stratouly said. 'The fact that I have spent time working on the convention center is widely known. And this is a new board that I don't have any relationship with. That board came in as we exited ... so I think enough time has lapsed that there is no holdover knowledge.' James Rooney, the MCCA's executive director, declined an interview request yesterday. But during a break at his board's expansion committee meeting Friday he denied any favoritism would be given to his two former board members. 'There is a process. I'm sure it will be a rigorous process that is devoid of who the players are,' Rooney said. 'It's a very rational process involving capacity to build a hotel, the design, the level of participation, and that is how they will be judged. I don't see that they have an upper hand at all. They will be tested just like the rest.' Neither Cowan or Stratouly have filed any conflict of interest disclosures with the State Ethics Commission or the MCCA.  State 'revolving door' laws permanently ban state 'employees,' including those who volunteer on boards, from becoming financially involved in projects they worked on while serving the state.  If the person did not directly work on the project but it fell under their official purview, there is a one-year cooling off period. Both Cowan and Stratouly have passed that period. The headquarters hotel is a '50-50 undertaking' between the MCCA and Massport, which owns the two vacant parcels bordering Summer and D streets where the hotel will be built. The MCCA said the first official action taken on the project came on June 20, 2013 - after both Cowan and Stratouly left - when both the MCCA and Massport boards approved a letter of intent to begin developing the hotel site.

hl1: In close race, Netanyahu vows no Palestinian state
author: KIMBERLY ATKINS
lede: WASHINGTON - In last-minute campaigning, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu yesterday said that if his party stays in power he will reject the creation of a Palestinian state, a pitch aimed at shoring up his support on the right in a hard-fought race.
body: 'Whoever moves to establish a Palestinian state or intends to withdraw from territory is simply yielding territory for radical Islamic attacks against Israel,' Netanyahu told the Israeli news site NRG. When asked if that meant no Palestinian state, he replied, 'Indeed.' Netanyahu used the backdrop of Har Homa, a Jewish settlement built on West Bank land annexed to Jerusalem, to warn that under his opponents, the center-left Zionist Union alliance headed by Isaac Herzog and Tzipi Livni would cede the area and allow it to be turned into 'Hamastan,' a reference to the Islamist militant group Hamas. Netanyahu's statements seemed aimed to halt the seepage of Likud votes to other conservative parties. Netanyahu's main rival on the right, the pro-settlement Jewish Home party, opposes a Palestinian state. While Netanyahu had been seen just a few months ago as likely to win, the election today in Israel is now more about bread-and-butter issues than the strained negotiations over Iran's nuclear ambitions, election-watchers told the Herald. 'The major political questions candidates have had to address are the price of cottage cheese and the cost of housing,' said David Harris, executive director of the American Jewish Committee.  Netanyahu's controversial address to the U.S. Congress and ongoing tensions with President Obama drew headlines here, but those issues barely registered in Israel, where Netanyahu's Likud Party is facing a strong challenge from the Zionist Union. Voters don't elect the prime minister directly, but if Netanyahu's party doesn't secure enough of the 120 seats in the Knesset, he could lose the post to Herzog - but that is one of several potential outcomes that could take days to emerge from this tight race and complex parliamentary system. The prospect of restarting stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, a top priority of U.S. Secretary of State John F. Kerry, also played a minimal role. Palestinians won't be watching the results, because they expect little to change, said Diana Buttu, an analyst and former spokeswoman of the Palestine Liberation Organization's Negotiations Support Unit. Herald wire services contributed to this report.

author: RICH THOMPSON
lede: Crimson guard Wesley Saunders claims to feel duty-bound by Harvard's traditions. His performance easily can be measured on a stat sheet, or by the many Ivy League accolades he's accumulated in his unprecedented run at the school. Saunders is a three-time All-Ivy League first-team All-Star and was last season's conference player of the year. But the 6-foot-5, 215-pound Los Angeles transplant needs to satisfy some unspecified obligations to coach Tommy Amaker and the Crimson players who've helped turn Harvard into a basketball dynasty.
body: 'It's great for me, but at the same time I can't forget about how it came to be this way,' Saunders said. 'It all started with the players before us paving the way and coach Amaker really getting us to buy into his system.' Saunders will compete in his sixth NCAA tournament game when 13th-seeded Harvard (22-7) engages fourth-seeded North Carolina (24-11) in the second round of the West Regional on Thursday night at Jacksonville Veterans Memorial Arena in Florida. 'This has been great to see how everything has come together to get us to this point and time,' said Saunders. 'I have just been lucky enough to be here at the right time but honestly, it's about the players before and everybody before who laid the foundation of what we have achieved.'     Harvard has won 20 or more games in six straight seasons, captured a share of the Ivy League title in each of the past five years and will appear in its fourth straight NCAA tournament. The Crimson needed a dramatic 53-51 victory against archrival Yale in a one-game playoff on Saturday in Philadelphia to capture the Ivy League's automatic berth. The last Ivy League team to secure four straight trips to the Big Dance was Princeton (1989-92).  'We feel like we can compete with anybody and I think we've shown over the years we can be competitive with just about any team in the country,' Saunders said. 'We are looking forward to the opportunity to go out there again and just play and see what we are made of.' The Crimson have demonstrated they can respect the name on their opponents' jerseys without being intimidated. Harvard upset New Mexico in the second round in 2013 and laid a 61-57 beating on fourth-seeded Cincinnati last March. Harvard rallied from a 16-point deficit to put a scare into perennial Big Ten power Michigan State before bowing 80-73 to the Spartans. The confidence from last year's run can carry over against the Tar Heels. Harvard's projected starters are Saunders at off-guard, Siyani Chambers on the point with Agunwa Okolie on the wing and Steve Moundou-Missi and Zena Edosomwan underneath. 'I think a lot of time with us being in the Ivy League, we don't get the respect around the country that other teams and other leagues do,' Saunders said. 'So it's opportunities like this where we can measure ourselves against the bigger-name school and bigger-name conferences. We just want this great opportunity to compete, and we know Carolina is great team. They are big and fast, but they aren't bigger and faster than Michigan State.'

hl1: Robert Closson, at 81, of Canton, veteran and business owner
lede: Robert W. Closson of Canton, formerly of Brockton, a veteran and business owner, died Thursday. He was 81. Born and raised in Boston, Mr. Closson went to Farm & Trade School on Thompson Island.
body: He was a veteran of the Army National Guard and the Merchant Marines. He played the saxophone in the National Guard Band and attended firefighters school while in the Merchant Marines. He was also a graduate of the Peterson School of Steam Engineering.  He owned and operated a dry cleaners in Dorchester and later worked for FM Generator in Canton.  An artist, he was a member of the Canton Art Association and many of his works were in local art shows. He also painted at an art studio in Stoughton where he took art lessons.  He loved spending time outdoors and was an avid hiker and backpacker.  Beloved husband of the late Anna M. (Cappelletti), Mr. Closson is survived by six daughters, Helen Andrews of Brockton, Christina Closson-Breese, Patricia Closson and Virginia Smith, all of Whitman, RoseAnn Closson of Randolph, and Mary Jensen of South Carolina; a sister, Eudivilia Mahon of South Carolina; nine grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. A funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10 a.m. tomorrow  at St. John the Evangelist Church, Canton. Burial will be in Canton Corner Cemetery. Arrangements by the Dockray & Thomas Funeral Home, Canton.

hl1: No doubting Thomas wants to be in lineup
author: MARK MURPHY / celtics notebook
lede: As Brad Stevens repeatedly said last night, nobody wants to get back on the basketball court more than Isaiah Thomas. If only the Celtics guard's bruised lower back agreed. Thomas received the bad news during a meeting with Celtics trainer Ed Lacerte yesterday morning. The pain in his back was still too intense to allow him to play last night against Philadelphia, thus extending his absence to four straight games. And the time frame is worse. The Celtics leave tomorrow for games in Oklahoma City and San Antonio, and Thomas will spend that time getting treatment here.
body: 'He'll be reevaluated tomorrow, but right now I'd say it's unlikely he travels,' Stevens said before last night's 108-89 win against the 76ers. 'He's still three games away, which is too bad. He really wants to play. To say he's antsy is an understatement.' No further tests have been deemed necessary. 'Ed said it's as tough of a bruise as he's ever seen,' Stevens said. 'Nobody wants to play more than that kid. That's what I appreciate about him. He had himself convinced he would play the next day after he fell. Hopefully he gets better sooner rather than later. He's a tough kid. Nobody questions that. He's doing nothing running-wise, movement-wise. He started jogging on the treadmill. But he hasn't been able to push himself as much as he needed to.' College calling A source said that, if contacted, Celtics assistant Jay Larranaga will consider interviewing for the opening at George Mason, the program his dad Jim took to the 2006 Final Four. Larranaga is said to look on the matter with due diligence, as opposed to genuine interest, as well as respect for his father's former program. 'He loves working for Brad (Stevens) and the Celtics,' said the source, indicating that it would take a very special situation - another NBA job - for Larranaga to leave the Celtics.  A league source said that Larranaga, who interviewed for the 76ers job last season, can expect to be getting more calls from NBA teams. 'The reality is that I'd be surprised if Jay wants that job,' the source said. 'He's going to have chances at head NBA jobs. If he went to George Mason, that would hurt his chances.' Stevens said he certainly understands the interest. 'It would be smart to pursue him, but I don't know what his interests are,' he said. 'He's just a really good basketball guy. He's smart, he works really hard, he's positive. I've talked about our staff and how great they've been all year. Any of those guys would be good for opportunities like that. One thing I'm excited about is that I have a chance to work with those guys every day, because I learn more from them than they do from me.' Home or away The Celtics now have won nine of their past 10 home games.Though Stevens emphasized execution on the second night of back-to-backs, he doesn't feel the need to stress something similar about home or road performance. 'It's important to me, and I said at the lowest of points, that in here you represent yourself like a Boston sports team should and play the right way, with the right mindset, the right toughness,' he said. 'But I don't talk about home and the road other than that. But yeah, we'll happily ride the momentum of a home crowd. There's an expectation to play the right way here, and we expect that of ourselves. You make too big a deal of the road, and then you think you're going to get a better deal at home and that's not how it works. You make a big deal of home, and then you make the road out to be this unconquerable mountain. So you play 50-by-94 feet and try to play well.  'That's one thing I learned from my first coaches - don't make things bigger than they are.'

hl2: Dance to fifth win in a row
author: MARK MURPHY
lede: Gino made an appearance last night. Brad Stevens knows the cause of his cameos is a truly rare thing. 'It's nice when you have a game where you're making every shot, but that's one of those nights, and one of those nights is called that for a reason,' he said recently. 'You're not going to have it very often.' But after starting the game with a four-game winning streak comprised of grind-style basketball, the Celtics were apparently due to put Gino's disco video up on the Jumbotron.
body: They completed a season sweep of Philadelphia, all by double digits, with the 108-89 win, and never led by fewer than 16 points after the first quarter. The win briefly moved them into a tie with Indiana and Charlotte (which played last night) for the seventh playoff seed in the Eastern Conference standings. All five starters cracked double figures, including a 20-point, 10-rebound double-double from Avery Bradley, and Gigi Datome and Jae Crowder each brought 10 points off the bench. The Celtics, after shooting as high as 70 percent in the first quarter, closed out shooting a clean 50 percent. Brandon Bass, who had lamented Saturday night at Indianapolis that he hasn't seen Gino for awhile, got his wish last night. Stepping into the old Kevin Garnett role, the Celtics forward put his arm around Gerald Wallace's shoulders and pointed up at the Jumbotron, dissecting the dance master's moves. The Celtics thus won their fifth straight game, and their seventh in the last eight. The C's started their fourth straight quarter with a burst, pushing out as far as a 25-point (95-70) lead before the Sixers resumed making shots. Though they eventually gave in to a stretch of sloppiness, the Celtics did enough to preserve the comfortable margin. Four straight points from Tyler Zeller (game-high 26 points), including a run at the rim off a high pick and roll, was good for a 103-82 Celtics lead with 2:57 left. Strong first halves have often been followed by flat third quarters this season, but not this time. The Celtics hit eight of their first 10 shots in the third, moved up by 23 points (75-52) on a Marcus Smart three-point play, and continued to simply have one of those nights. Zeller, who had a layup off a Bass feed during that stretch, popped out to the top of the circle to hit jumpers on back-to-back possessions for a 79-57 Celtics lead with 4:05 left. Bradley and Zeller each had 18 points at this point, and Smart became the fifth starter to crack double figures with a 3-pointer. Though the Sixers had finally struck a groove, too, with a 34-point third quarter, the Celtics were busy lighting up for a 32-point frame of their own. Though Philadelphia cut the Celtics' lead to 85-68 with 1:25 left, Crowder closed out the third with back-to-back hoops for an 89-68 Celtics lead. The Celtics, Saturday's high-quality win in Indianapolis tucked away, celebrated in the opening 12 minutes. They departed for the second with a whopping 38-18 lead after shooting 67 percent from the floor. Zeller and Bradley - the latter breaking out of a short slump - each had 10 points by the end of the quarter. Zeller was a perfect 4-for-4. Datome opened the second quarter with his second 3-pointer of the night, continuing to push the Celtics on to greater offensive things. By the time Bradley buried his third trey of the first half on the end of a 9-1 run, the Celtics led, 51-24. Evan Turner scored the Celtics' next six points, including a 15-foot turnaround for a 57-31 lead with 1:23 left. They led at the half, 57-34.

hl1: Video bust for Hub heist flick
author: GAYLE FEE / INSIDE TRACK
lede: 'The Forger,' the John Travolta-Christopher Plummer art-heist flick that was filmed in Boston almost two years ago, is finally getting a release - and it's going straight to video!
body: The film, about an aging art prodigy who has to steal a Monet from the Museum of Fine Arts and replace it with a forgery, will have an exclusive run on DirectTV starting March 26. Then it gets a limited theatrical release on April 24, and pops up on Video On Demand. 'The Forger' is the second flick with usually bankable stars to go direct to video this month. It follows 'Serena,' which stars two of the hottest names in Hollywood - Jennifer Lawrence and Bradley Cooper - down the on-demand route. And like 'Serena,' 'The Forger' languished unreleased for many months, and suffered from some less-than-enthusiastic reviews. The flick was filmed entirely in Boston in 2013 and a just-released trailer features shots of the Tobin Bridge, the MFA, a framed David Ortiz jersey and Travolta struggling with an on-again, off-again Boston accent. It debuted at last year's Toronto Film Festival and the critics were less than impressed. 'The opening shot in 'The Forger' is of a haggard John Travolta sitting in a prison cell, and the despair etched into his face suggests the actor might already be contemplating how wrong he is for this role,' said The Hollywood Reporter, which went on to call the flick 'a contrived thriller that wraps a gritty Boston milieu redolent of a Dennis Lehane story around a sentimental heart, with a high-stakes art heist that belongs in a more robustly plotted Hollywood studio picture.' Variety predicted that it would do weak business at the box office - which is the likely reason for the video release. 'Home-turf theatrical biz is likely to be flaccid,' said the show biz bible. 'Although cast names and genre elements will make this a viable, if uninspired, ancillary and minor theatrical item in most territories.' 'The Forger' was one of five high-profile projects to film in Massachusetts in 2013. 'American Hustle,' with the aforementioned Lawrence and Cooper; 'The Judge' with Robert Downey Jr.; 'The Equalizer' with Denzel Washington;and the HBO miniseries 'Olive Kitteridge' with Frances McDormand were all filmed around the same time as the Travolta flick, and all were released last year. 'The Forger' was one of the first films acquired by the newly formed Saban Films, which picked up domestic distribution rights it at the Toronto film fest for $2.5 million. The studio also bought 'Tracers,' starring 'Twilight' teenthrob Taylor Lautner, which also went direct to video. File Under: (On) Demand-ing Role.
